docs.title: Welcome to Biology Problems
docs.text: Explore free and open problem sets for Biochemistry, Genetics, and more! Click on a subject to get started.

docs.title: Subjects
docs.text:
• Biochemistry
  • Genetics

docs.title: List of Biochemistry Topics
docs.text: Explore the foundational concepts and techniques in Biochemistry. Click on a topic to dive deeper.

docs.title: Topics
docs.text:
1. The Molecular Design of Life

    • Molecular design of life, major elements, and biomacromolecules.

  2. Water Chemistry and pH

    • Properties of water, pH, pKa, and buffering systems.

  3. Amino Acids

    • Amino acid structure, types, and roles in protein structure.

  4. Proteins: Structure and Folding

    • Protein folding, structural levels, and mechanisms.

  5. Protein Purification Techniques

    • Isolation and analysis methods, chromatography, electrophoresis.

  6. Enzymes Reactions and Thermodynamics

    • Enzyme functions, substrate binding, and energy changes in reactions.

  7. Enzyme Kinetics and Inhibition

    • Reaction rates, enzyme efficiency, and inhibition mechanisms.

  8. Ligand Binding, Allostery, and Regulation

    • Ligand binding, allosteric effects, and feedback regulation.

  9. Carbohydrates: Monosaccharides to Polysaccharides

    • Carbohydrate structure, glycosidic bonds, biological roles.

  10. Nucleic Acids: Structure and Applications

    • Nucleotide structure, DNA/RNA functions, biotechnology applications.

  11. Biochemistry of Human Senses

    • Taste, smell, hearing, sight, and touch.

docs.title: Topic 1: The Molecular Design of Life
docs.text: Molecular design of life, major elements, and biomacromolecules.

docs.title: Types of Chemical Bonds
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT "Click to show example problem on Types of Chemical Bonds"

Which one of the following types of chemical bonds correspond to the example 'S - H (in hydrogen sulfide, H2S)'.

  • A. hydrogen bond
  • B. ionic bond
  • C. non-polar covalent bond
  • D. polar covalent bond
Check Answer

docs.title: The Seven Biochemical Functional Groups
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT "Click to show example problem on The Seven Biochemical Functional Groups"

Which one of the following seven biochemical functional groups correspond to the description 'Glucose and other sugars contain many of these chemical functional groups'.

  • A. Amino
  • B. Hydroxl
  • C. Methyl
  • D. Phosphate
Check Answer

docs.title: Types of Macromolecules
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT "Click to show example problem on Types of Macromolecules"

Which one of the following types of macromolecules correspond to the macromolecule 'glucose'.

  • A. carbohydrates
  • B. lipids
  • C. nucleic acids
  • D. proteins
Check Answer

docs.title: Hydrophobic Compounds from Molecular Formulas
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT "Click to show example problem on Hydrophobic Compounds from Molecular Formulas" Based on their molecular formula, which one of the following compounds is most likely hydrophobic?
  • A. acetate, C2H3O2
  • B. ethanol, CH3CH2OH 
  • C. phosphoric acid, H3PO4
  • D. butane, CH3CH2CH2CH3
  • E. erythrose, C4H8O4
Check Answer

docs.title: Macromolecule Types Based on Chemical Structures
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT "Click to show example problem on Macromolecule Types Based on Chemical Structures" Guide to Identifying the Chemical Structures of Macromolecules Carbohydrates (monosaccharides)
  • Should have about the same number of oxygens as carbons.
  • Look for hydroxyl groups (–OH) attached to the carbon atoms.
  • Carbonyl groups (C=O) are often present as well.
  • Look for the base unit of CH2O.
  • Larger carbohydrates will form hexagon or pentagon ring-like structures.
Lipids (fatty acids)
  • Contain mostly carbon and hydrogen.
  • Very few oxygens and often no nitrogens.
  • Fats and oils will have carboxyl groups (–COOH) and ester bonds
  • Look for long chains or ring structures of only carbon and hydrogen.
  • Steroids have four interconnected carbon rings.
Proteins (amino acids and dipeptides)
  • Always have a nitrogen/amino group (–NH2 or –NH3+)
  • Always have a carboxyl group (–COOH or –COO-)
  • Identify the central Cα (alpha-carbon) attached to an amino group and a carboxyl group
  • Larger protein macromolecules will have a characteristic peptide bond (C–N)
  • Try to identify common side chains (R groups).
Nucleic acids (nucleobases)
  • Must have a nucleobase, rings containing carbon and nitrogen.
  • Larger nucleic acids will have a sugar backbone and phosphate groups.
Phosphate groups (–PO42-)
  • Found in all of the macromolecule types.
  • It is best to ignore them to not let them confuse you.
  • The breakdown of carbohydrates involves add phosphates.
  • Membrane lipids have phosphate head groups.
  • Many proteins are phosphorylated for regulatory purposes.
  • DNA has a phosphate backbone.
Molecule Information Full name N6-Methyladenosine Molecular formula C11 H15 N5 O4 Molecular weight 281.27 g/mol Image link link to static image Partition coefficient -0.4 logP C/(O+N) ratio 1.2 Which one of the four main types of macromolecules is represented by the chemical structure of N6-Methyladenosine shown above?
  • A. Carbohydrates (monosaccharides)
  • B. Lipids (fatty acids)
  • C. Proteins (amino acids and dipeptides)
  • D. Nucleic acids (nucleobases)
Check Answer

docs.title: Topic 2: Water Chemistry and pH
docs.text: Properties of water, pH, pKa, and buffering systems.

docs.title: Correct Form of the Henderson-Hasselbalch Equation
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT "Click to show example problem on Correct Form of the Henderson-Hasselbalch Equation"

Which one of the following equations is the correct form of the Henderson-Hasselbalch equation?

  • A.

    pH = pKa – log10[Acid][Base]

  • B.

    pH = pKa + log10[Acid][Base]

Check Answer

docs.title: Optimal Buffering Range using pKa
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT "Click to show example problem on Optimal Buffering Range using pKa"

Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid and its conjugate base, EDTA, is commonly used in chelation therapy and as a chelating agent in biochemical experiments..Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid is tetraprotic with pKa values of 2.00, 2.67, 6.16, and 10.26.Which one of the following pH values falls outside the optimal buffering rangeof Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid?

  • A. pH 1.9
  • B. pH 2.9
  • C. pH 5.6
  • D. pH 9.0
  • E. pH 9.3
Check Answer

docs.title: Most Abundant Diprotic State at pH using pKa
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT "Click to show example problem on Most Abundant Diprotic State at pH using pKa"

Carbonic acid and its conjugate base, carbonate, is also known as respiratory acid as it is the only acid excreted as a gas by the lungs.Carbonic acid is diprotic with pKa values of 6.35 and 10.33.Carbonic acid has three possible protonation states in the choices below.Which one of the following protonation states is the most abundant at pH 9.5?

  • A. H2CO3
  • B. HCO3-
  • C. CO32-
Check Answer

docs.title: Most Abundant Triprotic State at pH using pKa
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT "Click to show example problem on Most Abundant Triprotic State at pH using pKa"

Arsenic acid and its conjugate base, arsenate, is extremely toxic, corrosive, and carcinogenic; it serves as a precursor to a variety of pesticides.Arsenic acid is triprotic with pKa values of 2.19, 6.94, and 11.50.Arsenic acid has four possible protonation states in the choices below.Which one of the following protonation states is the most abundant at pH 1.0?

  • A. AsO43-
  • B. HAsO42-
  • C. H2AsO4-
  • D. H3AsO4
Check Answer

docs.title: Most Abundant Tetraprotic State at pH using pKa
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT "Click to show example problem on Most Abundant Tetraprotic State at pH using pKa"

Pyrophosphoric acid and its conjugate base, pyrophosphate, is abbreviated PPi and is formed by cells from the hydrolysis of ATP into AMP.Pyrophosphoric acid is tetraprotic with pKa values of 0.91, 2.10, 6.70, and 9.32.Pyrophosphoric acid has five possible protonation states in the choices below.Which one of the following protonation states is the most abundant at pH 8.0?

  • A. P2O74-
  • B. HP2O73-
  • C. H2P2O72-
  • D. H3P2O7-
  • E. H4P2O7
Check Answer

docs.title: Topic 3: Amino Acids
docs.text: Amino acid structure, types, and roles in protein structure.

docs.title: Determining Dipeptide Sequence from Structure
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT "Click to show example problem on Determining Dipeptide Sequence from Structure" peptide_4529

A dipeptide is made up of two (2) amino acids. The figure above shows one such dipeptide with an unknown sequence. Your task is to find out the two (2) letter sequence of this dipeptide.Here is a step-by-step guide to help you answer the question:

  1. Consult an amino acid guide for reference. You can find a PDF guide on Blackboard under "Exam and Quiz" in the "Old Exams" section, with the filename bchm_exam-help_sheet.pdf, or search online for a visual guide that shows all 20 amino acids with their single-letter codes.
  2. Identify the amino-terminal end, represented as NH3+ and highlighted in bright green. Distinguish between the general nitrogens in amino acid backbones (denoted as NH) and the nitrogen in amino acid side chains.
  3. The one (1) peptide bonds connecting the two (2) amino acids are highlighted in bright green, making it easier to distinguish the two (2) amino acids.
  4. Examine the side chain for each of the two (2) amino acids to determine their single-letter amino acid code.
  5. List the single-letter amino acid codes in the amino to carboxyl (N→C) direction. This is the standard method for writing peptide sequences.

Select the correct peptide sequence from the options below:

  • A. QW 
  • B. FW 
  • C. MC 
  • D. QC 
  • E. YH 
Check Answer

docs.title: Identification of Amino Acids by Structural and Chemical Properties
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT "Click to show example problem on Identification of Amino Acids by Structural and Chemical Properties"

Which one of the following amino acids correspond to the description 'a negatively charged amino acid with a large, carboxylate (-COOH) side chain'.

  • A. glutamate
  • B. glycine
  • C. histidine
  • D. tryptophan
  • E. valine
Check Answer

docs.title: Amino Acids from Chemical Structures
docs.text:

  • A. arginine

docs.title: Topic 4: Proteins: Structure and Folding
docs.text: Protein folding, structural levels, and mechanisms.

docs.title: Levels of Protein Structure
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT "Click to show example problem on Levels of Protein Structure"

Which one of the following levels of protein structure correspond to the description 'formation of a β-strand within the polypeptide backbone'.

  • A. primary
  • B. quaternary
  • C. secondary
  • D. tertiary
Check Answer

docs.title: Hydrogen Bonding in Alpha-Helix Structures
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT "Click to show example problem on Hydrogen Bonding in Alpha-Helix Structures"

The α-helix is a right-handed coil in which each backbone N–H group forms a hydrogen bond with the C=O group of an amino acid located a few residues away. The regular pattern of hydrogen bonding stabilizes the helix, preventing it from unraveling.In a long α-helix, amino acid number 8 would form a hydrogen bond with which two other amino acids?Select the correct pair of amino acids below.

  • A. amino acids 6 and 10 (a residue shift of 2 positions) 
  • B. amino acids 5 and 11 (a residue shift of 3 positions) 
  • C. amino acids 4 and 12 (a residue shift of 4 positions) 
  • D. amino acids 3 and 13 (a residue shift of 5 positions) 
  • E. amino acids 2 and 14 (a residue shift of 6 positions) 
Check Answer

docs.title: Ionic Bond Formation in Amino Acid Side Chains
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT "Click to show example problem on Ionic Bond Formation in Amino Acid Side Chains" Based on the chemical properties of amino acid side chains, which pair of amino acids listed below can form an ionic bond between their side chains?
  • A. Serine and Glycine 
  • B. Methionine and Glutamate 
  • C. Isoleucine and Histidine 
  • D. Threonine and Serine 
  • E. Aspartic Acid and Arginine 
Check Answer

docs.text: Isolation and analysis methods, chromatography, electrophoresis.

docs.title: Cell Disruption Techniques Identification
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT "Click to show example problem on Cell Disruption Techniques Identification"

Which one of the following cell disruption techniques correspond to the description 'Cell suspensions are subjected to variable temperatures, resulting in rupture of the walls.'.

  • A. Enzymatic Method
  • B. Freeze-thaw
  • C. High-throughput Homogenizer
  • D. Sonication
Check Answer

docs.title: Types of Column Chromatography
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT "Click to show example problem on Types of Column Chromatography"

Which one of the following types of column chromatography correspond to the description 'only liquid chromatography method where molecules do NOT bind to the chromatography particles'.

  • A. affinity column (AC)
  • B. gel filtration column (GFC)
  • C. ion exchange column (IEX)
  • D. reverse phase column (RPC)
Check Answer

docs.title: Identification of Macromolecules in Gel Electrophoresis Processes
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT "Click to show example problem on Identification of Macromolecules in Gel Electrophoresis Processes"

Which one of the following types of macromolecules correspond to the gel component or process 'ultraviolet light (UV) visualization'.

  • A. Both protein and nucleotide
  • B. Only nucleotides
  • C. Only proteins
Check Answer

docs.title: Determining Net Charge of Proteins at Given pH
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT "Click to show example problem on Determining Net Charge of Proteins at Given pH" Isoelectric Point Problem Protein Name isoelectric point (pI) molecular weight Cobra Venom Factor (CVF) 5.2 149.0

The protein in the table (above) is placed in a buffer solution with a pH of 4.0.What is the correct net charge on the CVF protein at pH of 4.0?

  • A. The protein will have a net positive (+) charge. 
  • B. The protein will have a net negative (–) charge. 
  • C. The protein will have a net neutral (0) charge. 
Check Answer

docs.title: Protein Migration Direction Based on Isoelectric Point
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT "Click to show example problem on Protein Migration Direction Based on Isoelectric Point" Isoelectric Point Problem

A mixture of two proteins are to be separated by isoelectric focusing.

ProteinName IsoelectricPoint (pI) MolecularWeight Avidin (Av) 10.5 16.9 Estrogen Binding Protein (EBP) 4.9 115.0

Both protein samples are placed into a gel with a constant pH of 7.5. The gel is then placed into an electric field.In which direction will each protein in the table migrate at pH 7.5?

  • A. Both Av and EBP will have a negative (–) charge and travel towards the positive (+) terminal 
  • B. Both Av and EBP will have a positive (+) charge and travel towards the negative (–) terminal 
  • C. Av will have a positive (+) charge and travel towards the negative (–) terminal EBP will have a negative (–) charge and travel towards the positive (+) terminal 
  • D. Av will have a negative (–) charge and travel towards the positive (+) terminal EBP will have a positive (+) charge and travel towards the negative (–) terminal 
Check Answer

docs.title: Estimating Protein Molecular Weight from SDS-PAGE Migration
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT "Click to show example problem on Estimating Protein Molecular Weight from SDS-PAGE Migration" Gel Migration Problem

In this task, data from an SDS-PAGE experiment, where proteins are separated based on molecular weight, is provided. The gel results table below shows some standard proteins with known molecular weights and one unknown protein.

Protein Name MolecularWeight (kDa) MigrationDistance (cm) Ribonuclease A (RibA) 13.7 3.41 Avidin (Av) 16.9 3.24 Serine Protease (Ser) 22.0 3.03 Elastase II (Ela) 26.5 2.88 Horseradish peroxidase (HP) 34.0 2.68 Epidermal Growth Factor (EGF) 40.0 2.55 Sucrase (Suc) 51.0 2.35 Unknown ? 2.46 Estimate the molecular weight of the unknown protein by comparing its gel migration distance with those of the standards.
  • A. 15 kDa 
  • B. 20 kDa 
  • C. 25 kDa 
  • D. 30 kDa 
  • E. 36 kDa 
  • F. 45 kDa 
Check Answer

docs.title: Topic 6: Enzymes Reactions and Thermodynamics
docs.text: Enzyme functions, substrate binding, and energy changes in reactions.

docs.title: Energy Terms and Their Categories
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT "Click to show example problem on Energy Terms and Their Categories"

Which one of the following energy requirement categories correspond to the energy term 'Gibbs free energy greater than zero'.

  • A. releases energy
  • B. requires energy input
Check Answer

docs.title: True/False Statements on Chemical Reactions
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT "Click to show example problem on True/False Statements on Chemical Reactions"

Which one of the following statements is FALSE regarding chemical reactions?

  • A. Chemical reactions always involve a change in the chemical composition of substances. 
  • B. The rate of a chemical reactions depend on temperature, pressure, and the presence of catalysts. 
  • C. Chemical reactions always transform one or more substances into one or more different substances. 
  • D. Chemical reactions always involve the forming and breaking of chemical bonds 
  • E. For chemical reactions to occur, the chemical formulas of both the reactant and the product cannot be the same. 
Check Answer

docs.title: True/False Statements on Gibbs Free Energy (ΔG = ΔH - T ΔS)
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT "Click to show example problem on True/False Statements on Gibbs Free Energy (ΔG = ΔH - T ΔS)"

Which one of the following statements is TRUE of the Gibbs free energy, ΔG = ΔH – TΔS?

  • A. When ΔS > 0 the reaction is calledspontaneous
  • B. enthalpy can be described as the energy available to do work 
  • C. When ΔH = 0 the reaction has reached equilibrium 
  • D. Tis the temperature in degrees Celcius
  • E. ΔS is the change in entropy
Check Answer

docs.title: True/False Statements on Thermodynamics vs. Kinetics
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT "Click to show example problem on True/False Statements on Thermodynamics vs. Kinetics"

Which one of the following statements is FALSE concerning thermodynamics and kinetics?

  • A. Thermodynamics describes the equilibrium point of a reaction. 
  • B. Hydrolysis reactions often lead to an increase in the entropy of the products. 
  • C. Enzymes are NOT essential for most biochemical reactions. 
  • D. Enzymes do NOT change the standard change in free energy (ΔG°′) of a reaction. 
  • E. A reaction is spontaneous if the standard change in free energy (ΔG°′) is negative. 
Check Answer

docs.title: Topic 7: Enzyme Kinetics and Inhibition
docs.text: Reaction rates, enzyme efficiency, and inhibition mechanisms.

docs.title: Enzyme Inhibition and Activation in Metabolic Pathways
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT "Click to show example problem on Enzyme Inhibition and Activation in Metabolic Pathways"

A series of enzymes catalyze the reactions in the following metabolic pathway:

enzyme 1 enzyme 2 enzyme 3 enzyme 4 J  ⟶  K  ⟶  L  ⟶  M  ⟶  N

Understanding the type of enzyme inhibition or activation is crucial for developing effective drugs and understanding metabolic regulation.

enzyme 1 converts substrate J into product K.

The end product N of this pathway binds to enzyme 1and its substrate in the active site at the same time.This binding decreases the activity of the enzyme.Determine the type of enzyme inhibition or activation described:

  • A. molecular stopper 
  • B. competitive inhibitor 
  • C. non-competitive inhibitor 
  • D. un-competitive inhibitor 
  • E. enzyme activator 
Check Answer

docs.title: Enzyme Catalysis Terminology
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT "Click to show example problem on Enzyme Catalysis Terminology"

Which one of the following terms related to enzyme catalysis correspond to the definition 'either metallic ions or small organic molecules required for enzyme activity'.

  • A. Apoenzyme
  • B. Cofactor
  • C. Ligand
  • D. Substrate
Check Answer

docs.title: True/False Statements on Enzyme Kinetics
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT "Click to show example problem on True/False Statements on Enzyme Kinetics"

Which one of the following statements is TRUE of enzyme kinetics?

  • A. enzymes force chemical reactions to go forward 
  • B. enzymes can provide favorable microenvironments for a chemical reaction 
  • C. enzymes alter the equilibrium of the chemical reaction 
  • D. enzymes are needed in large quantities as they are used up in a chemical reaction 
  • E. enzymes alter the Gibbs free energy (ΔG) of a chemical reaction 
Check Answer

docs.title: True/False Statements on Michaelis-Menten Kinetics
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT "Click to show example problem on True/False Statements on Michaelis-Menten Kinetics"

Which one of the following statements is FALSE concerning Michaelis-Menten kinetics?

  • A. M-M kinetics assumes that there is no product available and there is no measureable reverse reaction rate. 
  • B. M-M kinetics assumes that the enzyme-product complex [EP] is short lived and does NOT contribute to the reaction rate. 
  • C. M-M kinetics assumes that the concentration of enzyme-substrate complex [ES] is constant. 
  • D. M-M kinetics was developed by American linguist Laura Michaelis and Belgian cyclist Milan Menten in 1913. 
  • E. When the substrate concentration, [S], is much smaller than KM, the reaction rate is linear. 
Check Answer

docs.title: Which Molecule Cannot be an Enzyme Cofactors
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT "Click to show example problem on Which Molecule Cannot be an Enzyme Cofactors" Which one of the following molecular entities CANNOT be classified as an enzymatic cofactor?
  • A. adenosine triphosphate (ATP) 
  • B. transcription factor proteins 
  • C. quinone, an organic compound involved in electron transport 
  • D. testosterone, an anabolic-androgenic steroid and the principal male sex hormone 
  • E. vitamin B7, biotin 
Check Answer

docs.title: Michaelis-Menten Constant (K<sub>M</sub>) from Enzyme Activity Data
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT "Click to show example problem on Michaelis-Menten Constant (KM) from Enzyme Activity Data"

Michaelis-Menten question. The following question refers to the table (below) of enzyme activity.

substrateconcentration, [S] initial reactionvelocityV0 0.0001  0.8  0.0002  1.6  0.0005  3.7  0.0010  6.7  0.0020  11.5  0.0050  20.0  0.0100  26.7  0.0200  32.0  0.0500  36.4  0.1000  38.1  1.0000  39.9  10.0000  40.0 

Using the table (above), calculate the value for the Michaelis-Menten constant, KM.

  • A. KM = 0.0001
  • B. KM = 0.0005
  • C. KM = 0.0010
  • D. KM = 0.0050
  • E. KM = 0.0100
Check Answer

docs.title: Inhibition Type Determination from Enzyme Activity Data
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT "Click to show example problem on Inhibition Type Determination from Enzyme Activity Data"

Michaelis-Menten Kinetics and Inhibition Type DeterminationThe table below presents data on enzyme activity measured as initial reaction velocities (V0) with and without the presence of an inhibitor at various substrate concentrations ([S]).

substrateconcentration, [S] initial reactionvelocity no inhibitorV0 (–inh) initial reactionvelocity with inhibitorV0 (+inh) 0.0001  3.7  0.1  0.0002  6.7  0.2  0.0005  13.4  0.4  0.0010  20.0  0.8  0.0020  26.7  1.6  0.0050  33.4  3.7  0.0100  36.4  6.7  0.0200  38.1  11.5  0.0500  39.3  20.0  0.1000  39.7  26.7  1.0000  40.0  38.1 

Based on the data provided, determine the type of inhibition show by the inhibitor. Consider how the addition of the inhibitor affects the initial reaction velocities (V0) at various substrate concentrations ([S]).

  • A. competitive 
  • B. extra-competitive 
  • C. non-competitive 
  • D. para-competitive 
  • E. un-competitive 
Check Answer

docs.title: Which Molecule Could be an Enzyme
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT "Click to show example problem on Which Molecule Could be an Enzyme"

Enzymes are biological catalysts that speed up chemical reactions in living organisms.Which one of the following choices is most likely an enzyme?Hint: enzymes often have a distinct naming pattern that can help identify them.

  • A. triglyceride 
  • B. intermediate filaments 
  • C. FADH2
  • D. manganese ions (Mn2+) 
  • E. acetylcholinesterase 
Check Answer

docs.title: Topic 8: Ligand Binding, Allostery, and Regulation
docs.text: Ligand binding, allosteric effects, and feedback regulation.

docs.title: Allosteric Enzymes in Metabolic Pathways
docs.text:
Blackboard TXT "Click to show example problem on Allosteric Enzymes in Metabolic Pathways"

A series of enzymes catalyze the reactions in the following metabolic pathway:

enzyme 1 enzyme 2 enzyme 3 enzyme 4 enzyme 5 J  ⟶  K  ⟶  L  ⟶  M  ⟶  N  ⟶  O

In a typical metabolic pathway, an allosteric enzyme is sensitive to changes in concentration of specific molecules and can regulate the rate of reactions.Which one of the enzymes in the metabolic pathway above is most likely to be an allosteric enzyme?

  • A. enzyme 1 that catalyzes the reaction from substrate J to product K
  • B. enzyme 2 that catalyzes the reaction from substrate K to product L
  • C. enzyme 3 that catalyzes the reaction from substrate L to product M
  • D. enzyme 4 that catalyzes the reaction from substrate M to product N
  • E. enzyme 5 that catalyzes the reaction from substrate N to product O
Check Answer
